verses.text: But on the first day of the week, at early dawn, they went to the tomb, bringing the spices they had prepared.
verses.comment: The mention of 'the first day of the week' highlights the shift towards Sunday worship among early Christians. The preparation of spices signifies devotion and the Jewish burial practice.

verses.text: They found the stone rolled away from the tomb.
verses.comment: This miraculous event indicates divine intervention, emphasizing that Christ's resurrection is an act of God, not man.

verses.text: But when they entered, they did not find the body of the Lord Jesus.
verses.comment: The empty tomb is foundational for the resurrection, providing historical evidence and fulfilling prophecies like Isaiah 53:9.

verses.text: While they were perplexed about this, suddenly two men stood by them in dazzling clothing.
verses.comment: The 'men' in bright clothing signify angelic messengers, signifying a heavenly confirmation of Christ's resurrection.

verses.text: As the women were terrified and bowed their faces to the ground, the men said to them, 'Why do you seek the living among the dead?'
verses.comment: Bowing faces to the ground is a sign of reverence. The question implies Jesus is alive, affirming the reality of the resurrection.

verses.text: 'He is not here, but has risen. Remember what he told you when he was still in Galilee,'
verses.comment: This fulfills Jesus' own prophecy about rising on the third day—a significant sign of His divinity and authority over death.

verses.text: 'that the Son of Man must be delivered into the hands of sinful men, crucified, and on the third day rise.'
verses.comment: 'Son of Man' is a divine title connected to Daniel 7:13-14. Deliverance, crucifixion, resurrection are prophecies Jesus repeatedly made.

verses.text: And they remembered his words.
verses.comment: The disciples often recalled Jesus' teachings after events occurred, reflecting the ongoing process of understanding divine revelation.

verses.text: Returning from the tomb, they reported all these things to the eleven and to all the rest.
verses.comment: 'The eleven' shows that Judas is no longer among the Apostles, marking the establishment of a core group of witnesses.

verses.text: Now it was Mary Magdalene, Joanna, Mary the mother of James, and others with them who told these things to the apostles.
verses.comment: Women serve as the first witnesses to the resurrection, showing a reversal of cultural norms and the value of faithful testimony.

verses.text: But these words seemed to them an idle tale, and they did not believe them.
verses.comment: Initial skepticism adds credibility to the accounts, as the disciples did not immediately accept the resurrection without evidence.

verses.text: But Peter rose and ran to the tomb. Stooping and looking in, he saw the linen cloths lying by themselves, and he went home marveling at what had happened.
verses.comment: Peter's eagerness and wonder underscores his leadership role and foreshadows his pastoral mission among the apostles.

verses.text: That same day, two of them were going to a village called Emmaus, about seven miles from Jerusalem.
verses.comment: The Emmaus event sets up a post-resurrection appearance, laying groundwork for Christ's teaching and revelation in the breaking of bread.

verses.text: They were discussing with each other all these things that had happened.
verses.comment: The disciples' conversation reveals their ongoing struggle to understand the meaning and fulfillment of Jesus' words and actions.

verses.text: While they were talking and debating, Jesus himself drew near and walked with them.
verses.comment: Christ’s post-resurrection appearances are physical, yet his presence is mysteriously veiled initially.

verses.text: But their eyes were kept from recognizing him.
verses.comment: Only divine revelation enables recognition of Christ. This also signifies spiritual blindness that only Christ can heal.

verses.text: He said to them, 'What are you discussing as you walk?' They stood still, looking sad.
verses.comment: Their sadness emphasizes their disappointment and misunderstanding about the Messiah’s mission.

verses.text: One of them, named Cleopas, answered, 'Are you the only visitor to Jerusalem who does not know about the things that have happened there in these days?'
verses.comment: This illustrates how public and dramatic Jesus' death was; everyone in Jerusalem knew.

verses.text: He said to them, 'What things?' They replied, 'About Jesus of Nazareth, who was a prophet powerful in deed and word before God and all the people,'
verses.comment: Their recognition of Jesus as prophet foreshadows fuller understanding of his divine identity.

verses.text: 'and how the chief priests and our rulers delivered him up to be sentenced to death, and crucified him.'
verses.comment: Their recounting highlights the guilt of both religious and political authorities in Christ’s suffering.

verses.text: 'But we had hoped he was the one to redeem Israel. And besides all this, it is now the third day since these things happened.'
verses.comment: Their hope in redemption is actually fulfilled, though not as expected; the 'third day' is prophesied in Hosea 6:2.

verses.text: 'Some women from our group amazed us. They went to the tomb early in the morning,'
verses.comment: The testimony of women ties back to the first verses and reiterates the authenticity of eyewitnesses.

verses.text: 'and when they did not find his body, they came back saying that they had seen a vision of angels, who said that he was alive.'
verses.comment: This angelic message supports the truth of the resurrection, with supernatural testimony confirming the bodily reality.

verses.text: 'Some of those who were with us went to the tomb and found it just as the women had said, but they did not see him.'
verses.comment: Multiple witnesses add credibility, yet physical sight of Jesus was necessary for final confirmation.

verses.text: He said to them, 'O foolish ones, and slow of heart to believe all that the prophets have spoken!'
verses.comment: Jesus rebukes spiritual slowness. Faith in the Scriptures is essential: all prophecy points towards Christ.

verses.text: 'Was it not necessary that the Christ should suffer these things and enter his glory?'
verses.comment: True messianic glory comes through suffering, as seen in the servant songs of Isaiah and throughout prophetic literature.

verses.text: And beginning with Moses and all the Prophets, he interpreted to them the things concerning himself in all the Scriptures.
verses.comment: Jesus personally reveals how the entire Old Testament points to himself—a model for discovering the spiritual and literal unity of Scripture.

verses.text: They approached the village where they were going. He acted as if he were going further.
verses.comment: Jesus gives the disciples opportunity to invite him, reflecting how Christ never forces union but awaits our response.

verses.text: But they urged him, saying, 'Stay with us, for it is getting late and the day is nearly over.' So he went in to stay with them.
verses.comment: Their invitation is a model for hospitality and echoes the disciples' desire for communion with Christ.

verses.text: When he was at table with them, he took the bread, blessed and broke it, and gave it to them.
verses.comment: The language here strongly parallels the Last Supper, suggesting that Christ reveals his presence in the breaking of bread, a pattern continued in later Christian practice.

verses.text: Their eyes were opened, and they recognized him. And he vanished from their sight.
verses.comment: Recognition comes through communion and faith—not only sight. Christ's glorified body is no longer bound by normal human limits.

verses.text: They said to each other, 'Did not our hearts burn within us as he spoke to us on the road and opened the Scriptures to us?'
verses.comment: Spiritual understanding often brings profound interior joy; opening of the Scriptures is a gift given by Christ to those who seek him.

verses.text: They rose the same hour and returned to Jerusalem. They found the eleven and those who were with them gathered together.
verses.comment: Their urgent return to Jerusalem shows the communal nature of early Christian faith centered on the apostles.

verses.text: They said, 'The Lord has truly risen and has appeared to Simon!'.
verses.comment: Special mention of Simon Peter's encounter highlights his special leadership among the apostles, and the apostolic witness.

verses.text: They told what had happened on the road, and how he was recognized by them in the breaking of bread.
verses.comment: Recognition in the 'breaking of bread' prefigures continuing Christian celebration—where Christ is known in sacramental moments.

verses.text: As they were talking about these things, Jesus himself stood among them and said, 'Peace to you!'
verses.comment: Christ appears miraculously, affirming his bodily resurrection and bestowing peace—a typical divine greeting.

verses.text: They were startled and frightened, thinking they saw a spirit.
verses.comment: Their fear testifies to the realism of the resurrection encounter; it was not an imagined vision.

verses.text: He said to them, 'Why are you troubled, and why do doubts arise in your hearts?'
verses.comment: The risen Lord invites faith over fear, echoing his commitment to strengthening the faith of the apostles.

verses.text: 'Look at my hands and my feet, that it is I myself. Touch me and see; for a spirit does not have flesh and bones, as you see I have.'
verses.comment: Jesus asserts the physical reality of his resurrection—a foundational doctrine for apostolic faith.

verses.text: And when he had said this, he showed them his hands and his feet.
verses.comment: The wounds in his hands and feet demonstrate continuity with the crucified Christ, indicated both by prophecy and eyewitness testimony.

verses.text: While they still disbelieved for joy and were marveling, he said to them, 'Have you anything to eat?'
verses.comment: His willingness to eat dispels the idea he was only a spirit, affirming the truth of his bodily resurrection.

verses.text: They gave him a piece of broiled fish,
verses.comment: Sharing food is both a sign of hospitality and proof of his real physical presence.

verses.text: and he took it and ate before them.
verses.comment: This act confirms that Jesus' resurrection body is glorified but real, not merely symbolic.

verses.text: He said to them, 'This is what I told you while I was still with you: that everything written about me in the Law of Moses and the Prophets and the Psalms must be fulfilled.'
verses.comment: This declaration identifies Christ as the fulfillment of all scripture (including Deuteronomy 18:15, Psalm 22).

verses.text: Then he opened their minds to understand the Scriptures.
verses.comment: True understanding of God’s word is a grace given by Christ. Spiritual insights are granted by God.

verses.text: He said to them, 'Thus it is written, that the Christ should suffer and rise from the dead on the third day,'
verses.comment: The suffering and resurrection of Christ are prefigured throughout Scripture, a direct reference to Old Testament prophecy.

verses.text: 'and that repentance for the forgiveness of sins should be proclaimed in his name to all nations, beginning from Jerusalem.'
verses.comment: Universal mission starts at Jerusalem, spreading to all peoples, fulfilling Isaiah’s prophecy of a worldwide witness.

verses.text: 'You are witnesses of these things.'
verses.comment: The apostolic witness is foundational; the apostles become the authoritative bridge for Christ’s mission and teaching.

verses.text: 'And behold, I am sending the promise of my Father upon you. But stay in the city until you are clothed with power from on high.'
verses.comment: The gift of the Spirit is necessary for ministry, and the apostles’ obedience models communal dependence on divine grace.

verses.text: Then he led them out as far as Bethany, and lifting up his hands, he blessed them.
verses.comment: Jesus blesses his disciples in a priestly gesture, reminiscent of Old Testament priestly blessings.

verses.text: While he was blessing them, he was taken up from them and was carried up into heaven.
verses.comment: The Ascension is Christ’s exaltation and enthronement, fulfilling Daniel 7:13-14’s vision of the Son of Man.

verses.text: And they worshipped him and returned to Jerusalem with great joy.
verses.comment: The disciples’ worship of Jesus is a clear recognition of his divinity, a mark of true faith and joy found in union with Christ.

verses.text: They were continually in the temple, blessing God.
verses.comment: Constant prayer and worship center the life of the early community around public Scripture, teaching, and prayer—laying a foundation for the Church’s liturgical life.
